entry.title: Combined summary - New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
entry.summary: Bitcoin developer Gloria Zhao has proposed a set of mempool/transaction relay policies to aid Layer 2 (L2) and contract protocols. The proposal introduces new policies for version 3 (V3) transactions, which are currently non-standard in Bitcoin Core. These additional rules apply specifically to V3 transactions, while existing standardness rules still apply. One of the key rules is that a V3 transaction can be replaced, even if it does not signal BIP125 replaceability. This allows for more flexibility in replacing transactions. Another rule is that any descendant of an unconfirmed V3 transaction must also be V3. This ensures inherited replaceability signaling when creating descendant transactions.Additionally, the proposal sets limits on unconfirmed V3 transactions to prevent malicious actors from preventing fee-bumping by adding many non-fee-bumping descendants. An unconfirmed V3 transaction cannot have more than one descendant, and a V3 transaction with an unconfirmed V3 ancestor cannot exceed 1000 virtual bytes in size. These limits help control the cost and complexity of replacing V3 transactions. The proposal also modifies the rules for package replace-by-fee (RBF) to ensure that replacement transactions maintain a sufficient feerate.The proposal aims to improve the flexibility and efficiency of transaction replacement, particularly for L2/contract protocols. It addresses issues related to pinning attacks and provides a more streamlined approach to replaceability signaling. The implementation of the proposal is available for review on GitHub, and feedback from the community is encouraged.In addition to the proposal for V3 transactions, there are discussions on other changes that could be made to improve the RBF system. Suggestions include making OP_TRUE a standard script type and allowing outputs below dust. However, it is agreed that these changes can be added later as they won't be standard until they are allowed.Concerns have been raised about the impact on the UTXO set and the chance of 0 sat outputs entering the UTXO set. It is acknowledged that while this may not happen often in practice, the chance is not zero. There are also discussions on limitations of the proposal, such as not fixing ANYONECANPAY situations or scenarios where HTLC/commitment-like transactions are being resolved in a batch. These issues may require a comprehensive RBF revamp in the future.The author clarifies that V2 and V3 transactions can replace each other to prevent censorship of shared inputs. Feedback and review of the proposal are encouraged, and links to the original proposal and related discussions are provided.
